Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-Density, Cost-Effective Electrochemical Power Management with Real-Time Diagnostics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Electrochemical energy storage in the form of large arrays of small to medium sized battery cells has the potential to improve U.S. energy independence, efficiency, and security by enhancing the capabilities of the electrical grid and increasing the viability and acceptance of widespread electric transportation. With the ongoing decentralization of the electrical grid and the growing penetration of low-carbon, but intermittent, renewable energy sources, electrochemical storage may play a critical role in maintaining grid stability while helping to manage energy flow between generation and end-load. However, modern battery systems are complex with a wide range electrochemical processes that underlie the simple metrics of cell voltage and current. Limitations of current battery management systems (BMS) result in system overdesign and operation well below maximum energy and power capabilities to minimize risk of catastrophic failure and meet operational targets. There is a clear need for transformational innovation in energy storage management technology, especially at the intersection of distributed power electronics architectures, control systems, and diagnostics. This project will support a collaborative effort that spans these areas of critical importance, while also supporting a range of broader impact activities through engagement in undergraduate teaching, K-12 students, and the general public.

In the collaborative project, researchers at Dartmouth will develop a new class of highly-integrated power electronics, used to manage individual cells in a large array, which will benefit from low-cost semiconductor batch fabrication, Moore's law scaling, and unprecedented performance in terms of efficiency versus power density. The Dartmouth team will also develop a multi-objective control system, implemented on top of the power electronics platform, to provide real-time diagnostics based on electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Researchers at Princeton will support construction of the platform at the embedded systems and software level and will develop the diagnostic toolset used to measure the state-of-charge (SOC), state-of-health (SOH), and pending failure modes of individual cells in real-time. To characterize the system and study EIS failure mode signatures, the Princeton team will design a series of batteries with known characteristics and flaws. This will open new dimensions in state-of-health diagnosis and provide the ability to fingerprint important physical phenomena across multiple time-constant regimes. By providing a realistic roadmap to cost-effective, highly-granular management and diagnostics, the collaboration has the potential to improve safety, performance, and cycle life while supporting reductions in pack overbuild and overall cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrochemical energy storage has the potential to have a significant impact on U.S. energy independence, efficiency, and security by enhancing the capabilities of the electrical grid and reducing barriers to adoption of low-carbon electric transportation. However, due to the many complexities of battery systems, a diverse range of applications with different array-sizes and configurations, and a variety of operating environments that may be harsh and/or high temperature, there is a need for translational improvements in technologies addressing battery management and diagnostic techniques.

This collaborative research project combined efforts at Dartmouth College and Princeton University in highly-integrated, efficient power electronics, and advanced electrochemical design, modelling, and characterization. The goal of the project was to explore a new roadmap for low-cost (truly viable) electronics that could be distributed in a large scale battery pack to manage the power flow in individual cells while also embedding advanced diagnostic functions to identify the health and capacity of the pack at a highly granular level.

The research effort had a number of important outcomes that could have an impact on electrochemical energy storage, power electronics, and the field of battery management. A first was the design of a multi-objective control system, implemented on top of an efficient power electronics platform, to provide real-time diagnostics based on electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The platform was able to apply accurately regulated perturbations of cell voltage (or current); by measuring the corresponding current (or voltage) of the cell, the impedance profile was reconstructed and used to interpret the underlying electrochemical state or health of an individual cell. This was initially demonstrated in a discrete prototype that used a conventional (buck-boost) dc-dc converter. A second generation prototype was also demonstrated that used a highly-integrated resonant switched-capacitor (ReSC) dc-dc converter. The integrated circuit (IC) prototype used a quasi-resonant 4-quadrant current-mode control scheme to achieve accurate regulation of cell voltage and current, while also providing capabilities for dynamic perturbation and time/frequency-domain cell characterization.

The IC solution achieved ~100x reduction of solution volume, ~10x reduction of solution area, and simultaneously increased efficiency (reduced power loss by 40%) compared to the discrete implementation and previously demonstrated battery management chipsets. Advanced instrumentation schemes were also developed that could accurately extract impedance information using a narrowband direct conversion (quadrature mixing) scheme. Solutions were benchmarked against expensive benchtop laboratory equipment (galvanostats) and found to be at least, if not more accurate in characterizing cell impedance.

The project led to the publication of seven peer reviewed conference or journal papers and the filing of two U.S. patents. At Dartmouth, it also helped support the training of 3-4 graduate students and the involvement of 2 undergraduate students. Broader dissemination and outreach activities included the involvement of the PI in bootcamps for high school juniors and seniors from around the country that exposed them to the details of energy storage and generation, and a number of presentations and invited talks at IEEE workshops and universities.
